user_request: Write a Shakespearean sonnet comparing a lover to a summer day.
final_poem:
My love is like the summer's flattering day,
When Phoebus paints the skies his amber fire
And every thing that lives doth take its gay
New life at his sweet influence. But, oh!  (refrain)

The gentle wind which from these lips does blow
Is fresher than the air that summer requires;
This kiss did make the morning that it showed
More welcome to my heart than that it dries. (return)

Yet summer, warm and long, often too much
His force spends late; and then we feel the gale
Of autumns coming with his gathering clouds,
Which chide against our love when we have most.  (refrain)

But love like morning keeps his beauties still—
Nor faints to give more light, but rather will.
(continue)
